a.text: Effects of aging on cerebral circulation and metabolism in man.

g.title: CarbohydrateReq117to142gd
g.text: The brain’s requirement for carbohydrates is in the range of approximately 117 to 142 g/d

g.title: CarbohydrateReq87to112gd
g.text: The overall dietary carbohydrate requirement in the presence of an energy-adequate diet would be
approximately 87 (117 – 30) to 112 (142 – 30) g/d

Reinmuth OM, Scheinberg P, Bourne B. 1965.

Arch Neurol 12:49–66

a.text: Reinmuth OM, Scheinberg P, Bourne B. 1965.
Total cerebral blood flow and metabolism.

g.title: GlucoseUtilizationRategConst
g.text: Regardless of age and the associated change in brain mass, the glucose utilization rate/g of brain tissue
remains rather constant, at least up to age 73 years

a.text: The cerebral blood flow in male subjects as measured by the nitrous oxide technique.

a.text: Sokoloff L, Fitzgerald GG, Kaufman EE. 1977.
In: Wurtman RJ, Wurtman JJ, eds. Nutrition and the Brain.

g.title: Carbohydrates100gdFuelsTheNervousSystem
g.text: 100 g/d amount of carbohydrates should be sufficient to fuel central nervous system cells
without having to rely on a partial replacement of glucose by ketoacids.

g.title: EARisTheSameForAllAdults
g.text: The EAR is the same for all adults

g.title: EARis100gd
g.text: Estimated Average Requirement (EAR) for Women and Men of >= 19 years:
100 g/d of carbohydrates

a.xlink:title: Raguso CA, Pereira P, Young VR. 1999. A tracer investigation of obligatory oxida- tive amino acid losses in healthy, young adults. Am J Clin Nutr 70:474–483. --> FREE!!! <--
a.text: Raguso CA, Pereira P, Young VR. 1999. A tracer investigation of obligatory oxida-
tive amino acid losses in healthy, young adults. Am J Clin Nutr 70:474–483.

g.title: In people who consumed a protein-free diet, total nitrogen excretion was reported to be in the range of 2.5 to 3.5 g/d (35 to 50 mg/kg), or the equivalent of 16 to 22 g of catabolized protein in a 70-kg man
g.text: In people who consumed a protein-free diet, total nitrogen excretion was
reported to be in the range of 2.5 to 3.5 g/d (35 to 50 mg/kg), or the
equivalent of 16 to 22 g of catabolized protein in a 70-kg man

g.title: PereiraBB->In people who consumed a protein-free diet, total nitrogen excretion was reported to be in the range of 2.5 to 3.5 g/d (35 to 50 mg/kg), or the equivalent of 16 to 22 g of catabolized protein in a 70-kg man

For a 70-kg lean male, this equals 56 g/d of protein which is greater than the estimated obligate daily loss in body protein from the shedding of cells, secretions, and other miscellaneous functions (approximately 6 to 8 g/d for a 70-kg man) and has been assumed to be due to inefficient utilization of amino acids for synthesis of replacement proteins and other amino acid-derived products. In part, it also may represent the technical difficulty in determining a mini- mal daily protein requirement.
g.text: For a 70-kg lean male, this equals 56 g/d of protein which is greater than
the estimated obligate daily loss in body protein from the shedding of
cells, secretions, and other miscellaneous functions (approximately 6 to
8 g/d for a 70-kg man) and has been assumed to be due to
inefficient utilization of amino acids for synthesis of replacement proteins
and other amino acid-derived products. In
part, it also may represent the technical difficulty in determining a mini-
mal daily protein requirement.

g.title: In people who consumed a protein-free diet, total nitrogen excretion was reported to be in the range of 2.5 to 3.5 g/d (35 to 50 mg/kg), or the equivalent of 16 to 22 g of catabolized protein in a 70-kg man->For a 70-kg lean male, this equals 56 g/d of protein which is greater than the estimated obligate daily loss in body protein from the shedding of cells, secretions, and other miscellaneous functions (approximately 6 to 8 g/d for a 70-kg man) and has been assumed to be due to inefficient utilization of amino acids for synthesis of replacement proteins and other amino acid-derived products. In part, it also may represent the technical difficulty in determining a mini- mal daily protein requirement.
56 g/d of dietary protein is required for protein homeostasis
g.text: 56 g/d of dietary protein is required for protein homeostasis

g.title: For a 70-kg lean male, this equals 56 g/d of protein which is greater than the estimated obligate daily loss in body protein from the shedding of cells, secretions, and other miscellaneous functions (approximately 6 to 8 g/d for a 70-kg man) and has been assumed to be due to inefficient utilization of amino acids for synthesis of replacement proteins and other amino acid-derived products. In part, it also may represent the technical difficulty in determining a mini- mal daily protein requirement.->56 g/d of dietary protein is required for protein homeostasis
UnderivedProteinIsTurnedIntoGlucose
g.text: Presumably the remaining difference (49 g) is metabolized and may be utilized for
new glucose production

g.title: 56 g/d of dietary protein is required for protein homeostasis->UnderivedProteinIsTurnedIntoGlucose
GlucoseProducedFromUnderivedProtein
g.text: From the 49 g of protein not directly
utilized to replace loss of endogenous protein or not used for other
synthetic processes, approximately 27 g (0.56 × 49) of glucose may be
produced.

a.xlink:title: Janney NW. 1915. The metabolic relationship of the proteins to glucose. J Biol Chem 20:321–350. --> FREE!!! <--
a.text: Janney NW. 1915. The metabolic relationship of the proteins to glucose. J Biol

g.title: JanneyBB->[Source not clear. Redirecting to closest source pointed at the text.]
It has been determined that for ingested animal protein, approximately 0.56 g of glucose can be derived from every 1 g of protein ingested
g.text: It has been determined that for ingested animal
protein, approximately 0.56 g of glucose can be derived from every 1 g of
protein ingested

g.title: JanneyBB->It has been determined that for ingested animal protein, approximately 0.56 g of glucose can be derived from every 1 g of protein ingested
The actual daily loss of protein is only approximately 7 g
g.text: The actual daily loss of protein is only approximately 7 g

g.title: [Source not clear. Redirecting to closest source pointed at the text.]->The actual daily loss of protein is only approximately 7 g
The actual daily loss of protein is only approximately 7 g->UnderivedProteinIsTurnedIntoGlucose
ProteinFreeDieteGlucosCatabolization
g.text: In people on a protein-free diet or who are starving, the 16 to
22 g of catabolized protein could provide 10 to 14 g of glucose.

g.title: It has been determined that for ingested animal protein, approximately 0.56 g of glucose can be derived from every 1 g of protein ingested->GlucoseProducedFromUnderivedProtein
The glucose derived from triacylglycerol, plus the amount of glucose potentially derived from protein, gives a total of approximately 30 to 34 g ([10 to 14] + 19)
g.text: The glucose derived from triacylglycerol,
plus the amount of glucose potentially derived from protein, gives a total
of approximately 30 to 34 g ([10 to 14] + 19)

g.title: ProteinFreeDieteGlucosCatabolization->The glucose derived from triacylglycerol, plus the amount of glucose potentially derived from protein, gives a total of approximately 30 to 34 g ([10 to 14] + 19)
The glycerol content of a typical triacylglycerol is 10 percent by weight, or in this case 19 g of glycerol, which is equivalent to approximately 19 g of glucose
g.text: The glycerol content of a typical triacylglycerol is 10 percent by weight, or in this case
19 g of glycerol, which is equivalent to approximately 19 g of glucose

g.title: The glycerol content of a typical triacylglycerol is 10 percent by weight, or in this case 19 g of glycerol, which is equivalent to approximately 19 g of glucose->The glucose derived from triacylglycerol, plus the amount of glucose potentially derived from protein, gives a total of approximately 30 to 34 g ([10 to 14] + 19)
ObligatoryProteinGlucose
g.text: The glucose produced from the obligatory turnover of protein plus
the glucose produced from glycerol is approximately 30 g/d

g.title: The glucose derived from triacylglycerol, plus the amount of glucose potentially derived from protein, gives a total of approximately 30 to 34 g ([10 to 14] + 19)->ObligatoryProteinGlucose
Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) for Women and Men of >= 19 years:\n130 g/d of carbohydrates
g.text: Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) for Women and Men of >= 19 years:
130 g/d of carbohydrates

g.title: EARis100gd->Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) for Women and Men of >= 19 years:\n130 g/d of carbohydrates
CarbohydratesFuelOnlyNervousStuff
g.text: It is provisionally suggested that an EAR for carbohydrate ingestion in the context of overall
food energy sufficiency be based on an amount of digestible carbohydrate that would provide the brain (i.e., central nervous system)
with an adequate supply of glucose fuel without the requirement for additional glucose production
from ingested protein or triacylglycerols

g.title: AcetoAcetateAndHydroxyButyrateMustnotriseTooMuch
g.text: The amount of glucose should be sufficient to supply the brain
with fuel in the absence of a rise in circulating aceto-acetate and β-hydroxybutyrate concentrations
greater than that observed in an individual after an overnight fast

g.title: AssumingAnAcceptableMacronutrientDistributionRange
g.text: Assuming the consumption of an energy-sufficient diet containing an Acceptable
Macronutrient Distribution Range of carbohydrate intake (approximately
45 to 65 percent of energy)

g.title: The decrease in brain glucose oxidation rate\nis not likely to be substantially less in aged adults
g.text: The decrease in brain glucose oxidation rate
is not likely to be substantially less in aged adults

g.title: The decrease in brain glucose oxidation rate\nis not likely to be substantially less in aged adults->EARisTheSameForAllAdults
The RDA for carbohydrate is set by using\na CV (coefficient of variation) of 15 percent to cover the needs of 97 to 98 percent of the individuals in the group
g.text: The RDA for carbohydrate is set by using
a CV (coefficient of variation) of 15 percent to cover the needs of 97 to 98 percent of the individuals in the group

g.title: The RDA for carbohydrate is set by using\na CV (coefficient of variation) of 15 percent to cover the needs of 97 to 98 percent of the individuals in the group->Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) for Women and Men of >= 19 years:\n130 g/d of carbohydrates
RDA = ((1 + 2 x CV) × EAR)
g.text: RDA = ((1 + 2 x CV) × EAR)

g.title: RDA = ((1 + 2 x CV) × EAR)->Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) for Women and Men of >= 19 years:\n130 g/d of carbohydrates
